Award.AwardTitle: Design of Complex Materials from Structurally Simple Gelators, Ionic Liquids, and Polymers and their Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, co-funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program and the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division, Richard G. Weiss of Georgetown University will investigate the structure and dynamics of self-assembly of molecules derived from naturally hydroxyalkanoic acids into fibrillar objects and gels and other molecules yielding new ionic liquids, ionic liquid crystals, and polymers. Some of the materials will be chiral and/or thermally or chemically reversible based on the uptake and loss of neutral triatomic molecules, such as carbon dioxide. By relating the structural and temporal evolution of the aggregation and nucleation processes, a correlation between nanoscale and macroscale objects will be made. The influence of solvent, especially as it pertains to the aggregation and growth of the objects, will be investigated as well. The overall objective is to create a picture of how and why molecules aggregate into the various one-dimensional objects so that the rules for such processes can be applied to a wide variety of systems. The broader impacts involve training graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs to solve interdisciplinary problems. In addition, the research will expose the young scientists to researchers from other institutions within the United States and in developing countries. While the research will primarily impact fundamental chemical science the outcomes will also be important for applications in which gels are important, such as oil recovery, art conservation and food science.

Gels are composed of extended aggregates of molecule, and are found in nature as well as industrial products. This research project will enhance our understanding of how molecules assemble into gel-forming structures and will form the basis for understanding more complex natural and engineered systems, such as how amyloid fibers form in the brain, how blood clots form and how better protective coatings can be engineered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary objective of this proposal has been to investigate the properties, applications and reactions of new molecular gels, ionic liquids, ionic liquid crystals, and polymers in order to understand their self-assembly. Some of the materials were chiral and/or thermally or chemically reversible. Answers to the fundamental questions asked and the materials being developed have led to some potential applications, including in the fields of art conservation, food chemistry, oil spill remediation, and synthesis. The results have also provided basic insights into self-assembly of other materials. The methods to achieve the objectives have involved syntheses,  calculations of molecular and aggregate properties, structural analyses at several length scales (in the Ångstrom, nanometer, micrometer, and millimeter ranges) and in different temperature domains (covering different phases of the materials), and dynamic measurements of structural changes.

Several detailed projects involving the structural and dynamic aspects of self-assembly of molecules and polymers into gels and related materials, and also analyses of intimate interactions between guest molecules and polymeric matrixes have been completed.  In each, a wide variety of experimental techniques, supplemented in most with theoretical calculations, has been used to gain fundamental insights into the requirements for the particular aggregated material to form.  Examples of the projects completed include: (1) a determination that diol stereochemistry, the number of carbon atoms separating the two hydroxyl groups, and the length of the alkanoic chains are the most important structural parameters controlling the efficiency of gelation of liquids by dihydroxylated derivatives of long-chained fatty acids derived from three naturally occurring molecules, oleic, erucic and ricinoleic acids (Figure 1); (2) the development of viscoelastic, gel-like, polymeric dispersions (HVPDs), prepared by crosslinking partially hydrolyzed poly(vinyl acetate)s with borax or boric acid in water-organic liquid mixtures, and  methods for making water-free HVPDs using trimethyl borate, boric acid, or borax as the crosslinker (Figure 2); (3) applications of the HVPDs for cleaning works of art, in collaboration with art conservators at various institutions, including the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC (Figure 3); (4) development of a technique for following sol-to-molecular gel transitions in real time using fast infrared spectroscopic methods (Figure 4); (5) application of Hansen solubility parameters to understand the rheology (elastic modulus ), critical gelator concentrations (i.e., the minimum concentrations necessary to allow gel formation at room temperature in a particular liquid), and the kinetics (gelation time, tgel) of gelation of sols with several molecular gelators and a wide range of solvents (Figure 5); (5) discovery and interpretation of an unprecedented gel-to-gel transition in a molecular gel; (6) analyses of the structural requirements of gelators for making thixotropic (i.e., mechanically reversible) molecular gels and development of methods for measuring the kinetics of their recovery; and (7) analyses static and dynamic fluorescence to determine that  chain relaxations, rather than hole free volumes, control the photophysical properties of luminescent reporter molecules in the polymer matrixes of poly(alkyl methacrylate)s (Figure 6).

These and other projects were designed to train of young scientists at all levels and from diverse backgrounds, including those from developing countries, by exposing them to a wide variety of scientific techniques and requiring them to use deductive and analytical reasoning skills in the interpretation of data from several techniques in order to derive cohesive hypotheses. That training has included opportunities to present their research results at conferences and to interact directly with students in other collaborating labs throughout the world.  Thus, each project was designed to require students to extrapolate from the known to the unknown, and to synthesize their own ideas. In addition, the PI has continued to provide service to the scientific community through his activities as an editor and a member of editorial boards for scientific journals, and as a pro bono consultant to scientists and institutions in developing countries.    

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2016
Modified by: Richard G Weiss

    "Structural and Solubility Parameter Correlations of Gelation Abilities for Dihydroxylated Derivatives of Long-chained, Naturally-occurring Fatty Acids" Zhang, M.; Selvakumar, S.; Zhang, X.; Sibi, M. P.; Weiss, R. G. Chem. Eur. J. 2015, 21, 8530-8543. (DOI: 10.1002/chem.201500096)

  • Grazing light images obtained (a) during and (b) after a cleaning test using a 4 wt % 80% hydrolyzed poly(vinyl acetate)/1 wt % borax dispersion with 40/60 1-propanol/water. The black ovals highlight the area at which the cleaning dispersion was applied and from which it was removed.
    "Structural and Mechanical Properties of 'Peelable? Organo-Aqueous Dispersions with Partially Hydrolyzed Poly(Vinyl Acetate)-Borate Networks. Applications to Cleaning Painted Surfaces" Natali, I.; Carretti, E.; Angelova, L.; Baglioni, P.; Weiss, R. G.; Dei, L. Langmuir 2011, 27, 13226?13235.

  • Offset FT-IR spectra, using the sol spectra as the baselines, for formation of mineral oil gels of 2 wt% (R)-12-hydroxy-N-propyloctadecanamide at different temperatures. Intensities increase with time.
    "Dissecting Kinetic Pathways to Formation of the Fibrillar Objects in Molecular Gels Using Synchrotron FT-IR" Rogers, M. A.; Liu, X.; Mallia, V. A.; Weiss, R. G. CrystEngCommun 2015, 17, 8085 ? 8092. (DOI: 10.1039/C5CE00733J)
    Richard G Weiss
    Figure 4
  • Representation of possible locations of pyrene molecules (blue) in poly(alkyl methacrylate) films with polymer backbones shown as curved lines and hexadecyl (PHDMA), ethyl (PEMA), butyl (PBMA), isobutyl (PIA) and cyclohexyl (PCDMA) side groups (red). Tm = melting temperature of the octadecyl groups.
    "Modulation of the photophysical properties of pyrene by the microstructures of five poly(alkyl methacrylate)s over a broad temperature range" Atvars, T. D. Z.; Abraham, S.; Hill, A. J.; Pas, S. J.; Chesta, C.; Weiss, R. G. Photochem. Photobiol. 2013, 89, 1346?1353. (DOI: 10.1111/php.12103)

Some of the materials were chiral and/or thermally or chemically reversible. Several detailed projects involving the structural and dynamic aspects of self-assembly of molecules and polymers into gels and related materials, and also analyses of intimate interactions between guest molecules and polymeric matrixes have been completed. In each, a wide variety of experimental techniques, supplemented in most with theoretical calculations, has been used to gain fundamental insights into the requirements for the particular aggregated material to form. Examples of the projects completed include: (1) a determination that diol stereochemistry, the number of carbon atoms separating the two hydroxyl groups, and the length of the alkanoic chains are the most important structural parameters controlling the efficiency of gelation of liquids by dihydroxylated derivatives of long-chained fatty acids derived from three naturally occurring molecules, oleic, erucic and ricinoleic acids (Figure 1);
